Reviews.Title: Surprisingly pleased
Reviews.Author: Kari S. Campos "Kari Silva Photography"
Reviews.Content: I have had probably ten different digital cameras over the last ten years, mostly Kodak, although the most recent ones were Canon.  I was spoiled with the 12x optical zoom on my Kodak Z1012 and the clear, sharp images it produced.  I don't want to carry it in my purse every day though!  I recently purchased a Canon SX110, which is small enough to carry daily and takes great photos; however, it doesn't allow for a date stamp except at 1600x1200 resolution.  After researching for several days online, I purchased a Kodak Z915 today.  Took it straight to the park and played with it.  Got some fantastic photos today.  I mean, I was surprisingly truly impressed by the clear, sharp images I got today for a relatively inexpensive camera.  I love the 10x zoom -- can't even imagine owning a camera with less after having that feature for a couple of years now.  This one does all that I need and does it well.  The movie mode seemed to have tiny shifts in focus while recording, but I don't use the video features on my cameras too often, so not a concern for me.  I may play with it some more and see if some tweaking of settings will allow for a smoother playback.  Again, can't say enough how happy I am with the image quality and that's my main requirement.

Reviews.Title: Under Priced Quality Camera
Reviews.Author: Michael E. Moreira
Reviews.Content: After a bad experience with another brand, I decided to go back to a consistant favorite of mine; Kodak.This Z915 model is exceptional for the price. I compared features across other brands, and this came out as the lowest price for the same features.10MP means you can crop the heck out of your pictures and they won't turn grainy. The 10x optical zoom is a deal-sealer for me, since you have the option of getting in close to a subject when you want, without using the 'digital zoom' feature thats on digital cameras (which isnt really a zoom, and cuts down on picture quality).Optical Image Stabilization helps clear up shakey shots, lots of options for both the beginner/casual shooter, and more in depth choices for the experienced photog round out this awesome deal.Choice of colors is a nice touch, the icing on the cake.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic photos for bargain price
Reviews.Author: peamom
Reviews.Content: I bought this to replace a Kodak z740 which also had 10X optical zoom and an eye finder, and took beautiful photos, but it was too clunky to fit in my pocket, and only 5mp with small screen so went in search of another camera. I first tried the Canon sx120IS, which was a major disappointment and you can see my review on it's product page. The Z915 on the other hand takes fantastic pictures. However, I must note that first camera I got was defective in that the outer edges of every photo were a bit blurry. I took a chance and exchanged for same camera as I loved the features and the great Kodak exposure. Well I'm glad I did because the new camera takes incredible shots.Here's what's BEST about camera:1) Sharp pictures with that wonderful Kodak vibrant exposure -- every one looks so warm and healthy.2) 10X optical zoom is incredible3) Camera has a "stage" scene that takes incredible photos of people on stage (I took some in off Broadway play) and camera makes no noise and no flash so no bother to the performers. If you have a kid in plays -- this camera is worth the price for that alone.4) Has a completely manual setting where you can independently set shutter speed, aperture, ISO, exposure and it will warn you in yellow if your settings do not jive with eachother5) Has a "High ISO" scene that takes incredible photos indoors in low light. I took some wonderful shots at an indoor basketball game where I was sitting 20 rows up off floor and zoomed in close to the foul shooter and pictures were great. (Note disable the flash or you'll miss an action shot - flash won't reach that far anyway).6) In display mode, has an "i" information button that tells you all the settings the camera chose even in scene or auto mode, so you can see what the shutter speed, aperture, iso, and exposure was for a particular shot and learn from it.7) Takes AA batteries which is super convenient. Batteries last days as long as you use good rechargeable batteries. Alkalines will work but not last as long. I bought a 15 minute Energizer charger with batteries.8) Super easy to operate. Very intuitive - you won't need to open the manual.9) Camera has does very well in minimizing noise. Check the online professional reviews and you will see the difference between this and the competition.Here's what could be better:1) This is not a sexy camera. A little clunky looking but fits well in your hand. Size tradeoff worth it for the 10x zoom2) Wish it had an eye finder for two reasons. Can be tough to see in bright sun. You may have to use one hand to shield the screen and the other to shoot. Also would be nice to have eye finder for the stage setting so audience at the play don't have to be bothered by the glowing screen as you take the pic (even though no flash or noise on that setting).3) I find putting the camera in P mode takes better photos than the smart capture mode, where the camera chooses a scene or settings based on what it sees. I took a picture of my kids playing wii video game in basement on both settings and the smart capture had some noise, whereas in the P mode where I left ISO in auto and let the camera choose everything else was noise free.4) The camera's find faces function is just so so, sometimes finding a few faces and not all. I found that if I want everyone pin point sharp in a group photo, hit the macro flower button on top of the camera to select Landscape (mountains icon appears), which gave me the most depth of field and everyone came out sharp - a must do for shots of people at a table where some close, some far.Note: The Kodak Z950 is the same camera, but a little smaller in size, 12mp as opposed to 10mp, same 10x opticle zoom, but proprietary lithium battery, and Schneider lens. It is a bit more expensive so if you want smaller size and proprietary battery (plan another $30 for extra battery and $40 is you want external charger), then try that one.Bottom line this is a great camera with stupendous optical zoom for a bargain basement price compared to the competetion. I gave it only a 3 star for portability as it is a little clunky compared to say the Panasonic Lumix with similar zoom. It's super easy to operate, but allows you many manual controls and a stage scene I've never seen on another camera. Can't wait for the kids' plays!

Reviews.Title: Clear, detailed pictures
Reviews.Author: K. Borah
Reviews.Content: I bought the camera for the 10X optical zoom, because I'd like to get closer up pictures at concerts and I'm looking forward to taking pictures in the mountains this year with it. I already had a good Kodak camera, but with less zoom and less megapixels. So far, I haven't gotten to check out the zoom for things like that, but I've taken some close up pictures of a butterfly and gotten clear, detailed pictures. You can even see the barbs on its legs. It's easy to use, I like being able to crop my pictures on the camera, you can even add a sound tag onto your picture. I like that you can put it on smart capture and the camera does the work for you. Its a good, sturdy camera and even though I had read reviews that it was a little bulky, it is smaller than my last digital camera and doesn't feel bulky to me at all. So far, loving this camera!

Reviews.Title: Pro says: Exceptional camera at a ridiculous price!!
Reviews.Author: Larry D Blumenthal "Apollo sings!"
Reviews.Content: Please read carefully: this is from a 35-year veteran Hollywood photographic professional who is both a still photographer and cinematographer. I carefully read the many reviews of the Kodak Z915, a very inexpensive digital camera. I noted comments of both those who raved about, as well as those who panned, this camera's performance. In fact, some of the criticisms gave me pause when deciding to buy my wife this model as a new camera for her birthday. She loves to shoot, but has no interest in a Canon D5 or such style of photographic gear. But quick photos from her cell phone were becoming a liability, especially considering her rather keen photographic eye and sense. So, without wanting to overwhelm her positive natural and artistic instincts with new gear of such professional level that she would be stifled by HAVING to control too much minutia, I decided to get her something viable for good results, yet not a fortune to buy or too complicated to learn! I am happy to report this gift was a huge hit! And here's why:1) First, fully ignore the complaints or bad reviews - either they know nothing about cameras or photography, can't follow instructions, or are simply too effing stupid or lazy to read the VERY CLEAR manual included. But mostly, these are people who go to taco bell expecting elegant epicurean dining. All my fears were allayed when I saw the Z915 in person.2) The camera functions as described and has exceeded ALL my possible expectations.3) The photos it produces, and the available functions to produce them, stagger the mind at this price!!!!!!4) The Schneider optics on this optical 10:1 zoom tracks well, has sparkling crisp resolution and is beautifully color corrected for achromatic distortion - very important for longer lens shooting - especially when combined with ...5) ...the amazing 10.5 megapixel resolution of this extraordinary consumer level camera system! There is plenty of room for up to even a another 5x digital zoom-in beyond the optical zoom limits to keep the image moderately clean on a 5x8 printed photograph. Bravo. In other words, if you were to crop an image to include only the words THIS IS ALL I WANT IN MY PIC from this review, it would still be a clear clean image.6) The features are perfect and all work well, from the SmartCam all-auto-point-and-shoot setting, to the many options for backlit subjects, intentional far or near focus even while auto-focus is working, to a setting which is fully manual wherein you must tell the camera what to do in every way just like a pro upscale still SLR camera. Plenty of shutter flexibility for sports, very fast turn around time for quick shots, quality for portraits and nature photography, lotsa special stuff for things like fireworks, red-eye, even document archiving! The only drawback I had was the lack of through-the-lens occular viewfinder for the eye. But most folks will prefer the wonderful LCD imager on the camera viewfinder anyway, which is set at half brightness from the factory and can be turned up for fair viewing even in sunshine! A viewfinder shroud can help this along for quite satisfactory results.7) And if all this isn't enough, the camera does amazing 3-panel digitally stiched panorama shots, and will video record image and sound in crisp Standard Definition video quite nicely. How fun. I noticed a couple folks bitched that the sound recorded was way down and therefore a big problem. As I said before, those morons are the problem. If they had simply looked at the diagram in the manual which tells you where the microphone is located (holes just at 10 0'clock of the lens housing), then they would have realized they had put their finger over the mic holes while they were video recording. Normally their forefinger should be on the zoom control anyway!In closing, let me just say that as a Hollywood photography professional there was no way was I going to just toss mama this camera, say "have fun" and then walk away. I did what all us camera and cinema geeks do - and that is take this little model through its paces. I am frankly shocked that Kodak pulled all this off for $120. No, it's not a high end professional replacement by any means, but my honey will no doubt take some amazing shots which might rival anything I would have"planned" to do with my Canon or Nikon. Eat your heart out Canon and Sony! Simply amazing.

Reviews.Title: Luv It
Reviews.Author: J. Goerge "Small_Town_Girl"
Reviews.Content: This camera is more than I expected. Much smaller than my older X4 optical digital Kodak camera. I love that I can zoom in and out while in video mode (maybe this is more common now but wasn't an option on my 6 year old kodak). I took video/stills at my daughter's swim meet last evening. I am very impressed with the quality and the zoom. I was able to capture her diving in the water (not even in sports mode). Only used this so far for this one occasion but this is exactly why I purchased it in the first place so I am very satisified.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic camera, even better price!
Reviews.Author: Bonnie DeMotte "MOM 2 4"
Reviews.Content: This camera is fantastic!  The pictures are beautiful, very clear in a lot of different conditions.  The lcd is large and has great resolution.  I recently purchased the Kodak m380, and the lcd screen was larger, but the resolution wasn't good, so you really couldn't tell if you took a good picture until you saw it on the computer.  I ended up returning that camera because it didn't take good pictures, and I really missed the 10X zoom.  This camera has the portability of a smaller "pocket" type camera, but all of the features of a full size camera.  It is also a lot easier to hold and handle than the smaller m380.  That one was awkward to figure out where to put your hands for a steady shot.  It was almost too small.  This one is perfect!  I really love it, and the price was fantastic.  I bought the red one because at the time it was $14 cheaper than the black one on Amazon.

Reviews.Title: A nice little point-and-shoot compact digital cam with a 10X zoom!
Reviews.Author: freestyleFrEaK
Reviews.Content: Let me first start by saying it's absurd and so trivial that some people feel the need to give a perfectly acceptable digital camera a poor rating because they can't get their pictures from it or because it doesn't come with a full page manual.  Frankly, people this dumb don't deserve to even think about handling a digital camera, let alone a computer.  It's 2010.  Today we have SDHC cards in digital cameras (jpeg compatibility), card readers, and printers (to print out manuals (even digital cameras costing 4X this price don't have printed manuals included).  Furthermore, if you don't like the software included with the product, don't use it.  Nobody's holding a gun to your head.  There are plenty of other photo software programs ready to accept your photos from this camera.  I don't care to dwell on stupidity so I'll move on.  I purchased this camera on an impulse buy.  I already have a compact Canon A590, and a megazoom Canon SX20, but needed a compact that had better resolution, and a greater zoom capability but wasn't as large as my megazoom.  I really wasn't expecting much from this Kodak Z915 and really was intending to return it after a few days, but upon using it for a week now, I'm fixed on keeping it.  The Kodak Z915 weighs approximately 280 grams with an added SDHC card and a good pair of Ni-mH batteries.  It measures 1.5 inches in depth, 4 inches wide, and 3 inches in height, with a 3 inch lens extension outward when in full zoom.  There is a mic pickup on the face, and a small speaker output on the top left of the camera.  On the top right we have a small power on/off button, a toggle in/out and snap button, a flash on/off button, and macro and timer buttons as well.  The camera looks slightly smaller in person than in pictures.  The body is made of plastic, aswell as the toggle switch.  All of which feel kind of cheap.  There is a program selection wheel on the top, and a color 2.5 inch lcd screen on the back along with four small function buttons running vertically along the lcd screen (delete, menu, info, and toggle camera / playback button).  On the side we have a port for a 3 volt in ac to dc adapter, and a mini usb out port.  In terms of selectable modes, we have a scene selection, a panorama option, a setting for "sports", a "smart capture" position for simple automatic point-and-shoot, a video mode, a "program" option (let's you set aperature, iso, flash advance or delay), an "aperture priority" setting, a "shutter priority" option, and a "manual" position.  The "smart capture" setting is a pretty straight forward selection for those phototakers who don't want to mess with settings and lets the camera set them, essentially letting you just point and shoot.  My favorite option though is the "scene" selection.  Kodak has built in 17 settings under "scene" that help maximize your picture quality depending on various environments and lighting conditions.  I find my pictures turn out a little better than just on the "smart capture" mode here with the "scene" choices. The "scene" choices include High ISO (for low light situations), portrait, night portrait, landscape, night landscape, flower (for vivid pics of flowers in bright light), sunset, backlight (for photos where light in behind the subject), candle light, manner / museum (where camera sound and flash are not desired), text (taking photos of documents), beach (bright situations), snow (bright white backgrounds), fireworks (displays of vivid bright night colors), children (playing in bright situations), self-portrait, and stage (for people on stage, less blur, more brightness, and no flash).  The camera doesn't have a true wide-angle position, but under the "panorama" setting there is the ability to take a 3 stage set of pictures from left to right, or right to left, and the camera binds all 3 pics (or "stitches" them together) for a wide-angle effect pic.  This is truly amazing and I've seen anything like it.  I've managed to put some fantastic panoramic pics together of some breathtaking landscapes with this option!  In the "menu" selection, we have 2 options for "capture" and "tool" settings.  Here we can adjust picture size from 10 MP (4:3), 8.9 MP (3:2), 7.5 MP (16:9), 5.0 MP (4:3), 3.1 MP (4:3), 2.2 MP (3:2), and finally 2.1 MP (16:9).  An excellent wide selection of picture resolution choices!  Under "tools" we can select the color mode (natural, high color, low color, sepia, and b&w;).  We can turn on or off the face detection option, set automatic focus to single or continuous, and set the LCD brightness.  Additional selections include image grid, red-eye reduction, date and time stamp, image stabilization, quickview, camera sounds, video out (NTSC or PAL), image storage (memory card, internal 32 mb only, or both using internal as backup for the memory card).  We also have language, reset, and format selections as well.  In terms of taking pictures and video, I find it's always best to know you're working environment and being able to fine tune the options on the camera for best photo and video quality.  Don't get me wrong, the simple "smart capture" mode works fine, but you can squeeze out some incredibly impressive photos from this little digital cam if you know how to get your settings right.  It's really something that comes with experimentation and experience.  The macro mode works well even though there has been some negative feedback about it here on Amazon.  Ideally, anywhere you have bad lighting, the macro focus won't focus, and you'll have bad pics.  I've managed to take some neat close=ups of flowers and other things at distances of about 3 inches, but anything closer causes the focus to blur.  The video is pretty crisp and sounds decent, but keep in mind it's at 640x480, so don't expect HD quality here.  Still, a nice little option for those moments you don't want to miss the "live" moments.  The use of a pair of regular AA batteries is excellent.  I don't understand why some people don't like using AA batteries?  A pair of high-powered ni-mh batteries will keep this camera running for hours under video mode, and lets you take hundreds of photos before needing recharging.  And if you're out on the road with no recharger, there's almost always somewhere you can go to pick up a set of alkalines for those occasions you need to get back to taking photos quickly.  The memory card slot accepts the largest card I have (32 gig) and when you're ready to view your photos is simple to remove and place in my laptop card reader or usb cardreader port on my dvd player.  A couple small things that i don't like include the fact that the LCD is hard to view in bright light and it's resolution is pretty basic, but don't let the pics on the LCD fool you, when you blow them up on your monitor many of them look incredible.  I've decided to keep this camera.  Why?  It makes my Canon A590 Powershot pocket cam perform like a dinosaur.  The Canon's pics look flat, hazy, and dull compared to the Kodak's.  I've taken both to the park and put them head to head.  The picture quality (resolution) of the Kodak, zoom capability, and video is just that much better than the Canon (I never would have thought that about a Kodak versus a Canon) condisering both cameras were released at about the same time (2007/2008).  So if you're looking for a VERY versatile pocket cam that takes great pics and good video at a price that won't break the bank, I highly recommend this Kodak Z915.  I have absolutely no regrets in purchasing it!

Reviews.Title: Love The Camera
Reviews.Author: Edith Brown
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera.  It has 10X zoom and 10 mp.  I already had a Kodak C613 with 3X zoom and 6.1 mp and I still consider it a very good camera.  I would never buy anything, from now on, with less that 10X zoom.  This camera has so many good features and I love the software that comes with Kodak.  Kodak is one of the oldest camera makers and they keep up with the times and people's needs.  It was reasonably priced and I would recommend this camera to anyone interest in taking some good pictures.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Bethany Lwaltemyer
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera for several months. I am very happy with it's performance and it's pictures after printing. I have used the various scenes to play with it, and have liked the outcome. Would recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Easy to use, lacks features in competitor cameras.
Reviews.Author: Senski "DennyD"
Reviews.Content: The staple of any Kodak camera, ease to use. This camera follows that mantra with easy to read and use buttons, and a setting dial on the top which makes switching between shooting modes simple. This type of camera, a high zoom with expanded shooting modes than a point and shoot, while still having the point and shoot philosophy so a early user to digital cameras or even a seasoned photographer can find ways to capture their pictures the best.What Kodak does so well also is something that sets it lower than what Sony H20, Canon SX120 IS, and Nikon L20 have in the class the Z915 is trying to enter. All of the other cameras feature better image quality, more custom modes where white balance, shutter speed, flash levels, ISO levels, and focal distance points are more expanded than what's offered in the Kodak. Also, the time between pictures on the Kodak is noticeably longer than the Sony, Canon, and Nikon. While many may not see that as a make or break when deciding on a camera, the wait time can be annoying for others.The Kodak does make a compelling case in the in-between segment of point and shoot, and having some settings DSLRs were exclusive to. And what the Kodak doesn't have compared to the competition, it does make up for it in the price, close to $75 to $100.

Reviews.Title: lovely camera !
Reviews.Author: Mar "Marinera"
Reviews.Content: I just got this camera today ! red ! love it.its little and takes nice sharp crispy pictures. colorful.its a bit heavy but thats fine,its cheap and good !recommend this camera to everybody.

Reviews.Title: Excellent design, good bargain.
Reviews.Author: Dion Smith
Reviews.Content: The 10MP with 10x optical zoom camera is fantastic.  Takes excellent photos, easy to use, reliable, and long battery life.  Costs less, slimmer profile, and same features as other major brands we looked at.

Reviews.Title: Very Good Camera
Reviews.Author: Mariano Andres Sanin
Reviews.Content: This camera works great in automatic and also provides lots of setup options when you like to go manually.  I really liked this camera because it works great almost with every condition of light and that's impresive for a non-professional camera.  The only thing i would change is the battery, it should be a litium one instead of the AA.

Reviews.Title: Get rid of the old SLR, technology is on the move
Reviews.Author: John E. Vidale "conventional Earth scientist"
Reviews.Content: I just bought two of these for my daughter, after web research, and am pleased.  It is better than my more expensive SLR bought just three years ago, she'd better watch out.  Despite her aversion to mechanical devices and reading instructions, she's off and running in a photography class.  Two excursions downtown this weekend, and she's already snapped 700 pictures and posted on Facebook (and gotten compliments for) at least 60 shots.This camera has the combination of moderate price, 10X zoom, fast exposure and focus, image stabilization, 10 megapixels, and ease of use that I sought.  The only other sensible alternative is a more compact camera, but those have much less zoom power - good luck getting close to distant or reluctant subjects with those.The first camera, however, was a casualty of a dropped backpack.  A minor scuffle led to a shattered LCD screen on the back, which is relatively exposed.  Nice that this camera is inexpensive.After quite a bit more web research and visits to Radio Shack and Office Depot, I found that the Case Logic MEQB series semi-hard case just fits the camera and comes in 5 comely colors.  Office Depot had that model, and it should protect the 2nd camera for at least a while, and I see it at Walmart as well.Don't forget to order a fast and ample SDHC card.  I got this one, although I'm sure cheaper ones would suffice:  Patriot LX Series 8 GB SDHC Class 10 Flash Memory Card PSF8GSDHC10 (Black) .  Internal memory is just a few mbytes.  Make sure you have the current version of EasyShare software (the version on the disk that came with my camera wasn't).If you plan to use the cable to download pictures, note that it is NOT a standard USB cable, rather this Kodak USB Cable Model U-8 $20 special order, so don't lose it as I did.  A $10 SDHC card reader also works, but the cable works better.

Reviews.Title: A Great Fit
Reviews.Author: Ken Ryan
Reviews.Content: First off; I bought this camera at Amazon and delivery was prompt. I have not had a camera since the "film" days. About 4 months ago, I discovered super zoom cameras on TV and began to look into them. I took a liking to the Panasonic zx3 because it would fit into the pocket and had a long zoom. I was saving up to buy one but wanted to examine at least one other camera in the same category.  Then I found the Kodak Z915. I knew it was slightly larger and actually had to hope that it would fit in my pocket. It does fit in my shirt pocket. At that time, I was saving to buy the ZX3. The Z915 already fit my wallet. It is $100 less than the ZX3. That's nice. I bought the Z915 about 2 weeks ago. Also, as I mentioned above, I haven't used a camera in quite a while. Now with this camera in my pocket, everything is a potential picture. The auto mode is quick; I can take this camera out, push the ON button, zoom to what I want, push the Shoot button half way until green focus box, and click it. This can comfortably take about 5 seconds. Finally it is good for learning. This camera has enough modes that I will be learning how to use them for quite some time. When I put my 4 gig data card in the camera shows that I have about 1200 pictures left. I have a whole bunch of aa batteries but regular batteries only last for about an hour and a half or so of shooting and fiddling with the pictures. The transfer to the computer was simple with the instructions given. Editing them there is pretty simple.  Sending some of them was not quite so simple but it did get done in about 10 minutes. It won't take but a minute next time. As you can see, I like this camera a lot so far. It fits my pocket, pocketbook,and is exactly what I needed.

Reviews.Title: Iguana ready
Reviews.Author: weRborg
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to shoot pictures of wild iguanas.  I needed something with a good zoom lens, because you can't get too close, fast and easy focus because iguanas are really fast when spooked.  I can't believe how good the pictures come out.  No blurring, great closeups, point and shoot.  For the non-professional this is amazing at a reasonable price.  It is also quiet without any bells to scare anyone and gets crisp sharp images with amazing detail.  The screen lets you see exactly what the picture you snapped looks like right after you shoot it so you can zoom in or out or center it better with the next shot. It all fits in a small inexpensive Kodak case (sold separately) for easy storage with extra batteries and flash cards.  I love this camera!!

Reviews.Title: Nice camera except for video which malfunctions intermittently
Reviews.Author: Photo Enthusiast "photo-enthusiast"
Reviews.Content: Nice camera for the price.ProsHas mostly everything I wanted-10x optical zoom-10MP-Manual controls (with light meter)-AA batteries-not a power hog - my rechargeable batteries work just fine-ability to hook up DC external power supply (for long videos)Cons-No view finder, so very difficult to see LCD in bright sunshine (problem with all LCDs)-The camera just loses control of Video (means there is no way to stop it or turn off the camera except to remove batteries). This happens intermittently for longer videos (beyond 4-5 mins). I lost some invaluable moments this way.Overall, a nice camera. Daytime shots are wonderful. Night shots are grainy but you can experiment with the manual controls. Can serve as a training camera before getting a dSLR.

Reviews.Title: Simple and easy to use AND takes good quality pictures
Reviews.Author: Leigh A. Curry
Reviews.Content: This camera is very simple and easy to use. I am  pleased with the quality of the pictures it takes and that it is not difficult to navigate through the settings. I was'nt expecting this camera to take AA batteries though. The last couple of cameras I've owned have used the rechargeable batteries, & I've found the one I owned to be unreliable at times when I really depended on it working,because the batteries have died & I didn't have time to recharge them. Now I just keep spare batteries with me & now I don't have to worry about that anymore.But overall, I would definately recommend this camera, and the color of it is really pretty.

Reviews.Title: Slightly Blurred Pictures in Auto Mode
Reviews.Author: Anthony
Reviews.Content: I was expecting this camera to produce sharp pictures with the added bonus of the 10x optical zoom lens.  The majority of pictures I took came out slightly blurred, especially indoors.  I checked to make sure image stabilization was on, which it was.  The only way I could get a good picture was to play with the manual controls and that method only produced mixed results.  I have already shipped this camera back.  I bought another camera at the same time as a gift.  It is a Canon PowerShot SD1200IS.  It is the same price as the Kodak Z915.  It is an awesome little camera.  The Pictures are sharp right out of the box in auto mode.  It quickly focuses as opposed to the Z915, which took 2 seconds to focus every time you zoomed in.Do yourself a favor and don't fall for the 10x optical zoom like I did.  The Z915 is a cheap camera that someone at Kodak stuck a 10x optical zoom lens on.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Another satisfied customer
Reviews.Content: This is an amazing camera, awesome options for the amateur photographer or more advanced options for those who would like a little more control.  The zoom is crystal clear.  I would recommend this camera to anyone, and a great price.

Reviews.Title: Great Quality Cam at Very Low Price.
Reviews.Author: Carl A. Crawford
Reviews.Content: This is an excellent quality, high zoom, very lightweight, easy to carry, Kodak camera for a bargain basement price. How anyone who knows anything at all about photography, including beginners, can not get a good pic out of this model camera is beyond me. The fact that it also has a nice, in camera stitch feature, for panoramic scenes up to 3 panels wide makes it an even better deal.  But, first, let's address some of the myths created by those that rated this cam with only a 1 or 2 star rating."Cam comes with very poor manual." Gee, do you think you might take 5 minutes and download the extended user's manual for this specific model and actually STUDY or at least READ it, if you can not figure this cam out on your own. It has an internal guideline system for even beginners built on the menu system, but still may be too much for some to digest and actually use._ _ _ _  " It eats batteries like nothing I have ever seen."  Amazing. They ALL use up and drain non-rechargeable batteries quickly. Buy a good set of rechargeable batteries like Eneloops and this problem is solved.  _ _ _ _  "The video sound is extremely muted."  Take your finger or thumb off the microphone. If you looked at the diagram supplied,you would know where it is, and it is very easy to cover it up without realizing it.  _ _ _ _  "The quality of the photos is mixed, and it takes very poor pics indoors."  Odd, when you are consistent, using good standard practices, you can obtainconsistently good results. The ONLY thing causing mixed results, is the inconsistent actions of the user.Regarding the poor pics indoors or in low light conditions, the vast majority of cams with sensors as smallas standard point and shoots are going to perform in a mediocre manner. This one performs no worse than several on the market that are far more expensive.  _ _ _ _  "This cam is all plastic and feels like it would break easily if dropped."  News Flash! Even a high quality all metal expensive cam may have the lens damaged by asingle drop, and be made non operational. DO NOT DROP IT!!!  _ _ _ _  The list goes on, and I will not bother addressing the rest of the comedy acts from fantasy land. Go to dpreview, or just look on this site at some of the examples of the photos taken. This is a VERY LOW PRICED budget cam that can often be obtained for around $100, and sometimes less than that. Out of all these whiners, complainers, moaners, and groaners, only a single one recommended something else by name, that he thought was better in the same price range. BUT, when I looked up that model, not only did it cost a minimum of $60 more, but it was not 10X. It was either 3 or 4X zoom putting it in an entirely different category, and it had some weaknesses I have not seen on this model at all.  The Kodak Z915 has 10X optical zoom, with 5X advanced digital zoom, for a total combined zoom capability of 50X. For such an inexpensive camera, while not perfect it is quite capable. It also has a quick turn around time in between shots, and overall works surprisingly well.

Reviews.Title: Bang for the buck!
Reviews.Author: Picture Taker
Reviews.Content: Kodak is back! A lot of bang for the buck. Higher end, Kodak has that too in more pricey models. Point and shoot, it does that too, very well. Custom semi pro settings, they are there. For less than a hundred bucks it's hard to beat. Details: Glass optics, mechanical image stabilization and zoom, aspect ratio selections (important) as megapixels aren't always everything. Just a good overall camera and the user interface is about the best out there.

Reviews.Title: Impressive pictures - worth the money but only if on sale
Reviews.Author: Yarii
Reviews.Content: Originally I ordered this camera in red from a well-known shopping channel a few months ago.  When I received it, the red color made it look very cheap, almost like a disposable camera, so I returned it.  I didn't even bother trying the camera out.Fast forward to last month.  This was a Gold Box Deal and the price was (and still is) pretty good for the bundle (the bundle comes with the case, rechargeable AA batteries and charger)--by the way, don't get the batteries confused - they also include the regular alkaline AA batteries - don't accidentally stick those in the charger like I almost did!I took a chance on the black camera this time and I'm still on the fence about keeping it.  I think the black color makes it look  more expensive than a disposable, but the plastic seems very thin compared to other cameras I own.  Time will tell on how rugged it is, since there were a couple superficial scratches on it the first time I took it out of the box...what happens after I use it for awhile - how many scratches will this get? I take very good care of my cameras but this camera body is so chintzy.Easy to use without reading the instruction manual - and if you do need help, part of the manual is stored on-board - just press the button on the back of the camera.  It takes incredible pictures, even better than an expensive Fuji camera I used to own.  You can include the date on the picture, something I had to add  myself  with software with any of my Fuji's.  I'm not sure about Nikon, but I think Canon is the only other camera manufacturer where you can include the date on the picture.The shutter lag time is fast enough.  I rarely miss a shot while waiting on the shutter to respond whether it be with flash or without. BUT---Kodak's way of doing the picture preview after taking a shot leaves a lot to be desired.  It's called QuickView.  You have a choice of it being "off", "5 seconds", or "10 seconds" - meaning after you take your shot, the picture will preview for 5 seconds or 10 seconds. I *really* hate this feature, a 2 second picture preview is enough time to check and see if the picture is OK.  I don't need 5 or 10 seconds - your only choices besides "off".However, with this "QuickView" feature which really isn't quick - there is a small paragraph in the manual which says you can lightly touch the shutter button and you can then go on to taking the next picture.  I completely skimmed over this the first time I read the online manual.  Kodak needs to put this in bolder type so it's more easily noticed.  I assume all Kodak cameras are this way, but I still don't like the way this operates.The two AA rechargeable batteries last about 180 pictures for me.  But I tend to leave my camera on most of the time and let it shut off on its own.There are also very few cameras in this price range where you can have full manual control should you want to - you can set your own aperture, shutter speed, flash compensation and ISO.And even though the movies are not HD quality, they are quite acceptable for uploading to YouTube.This camera was released over a year ago, and that's the reason for the price drop.  I am also currently checking out the Z950 Kodak EasyShare Z950 12 MP Digital Camera (Black) with 10x Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD which was released about the same time as the Z915, but has 12 MP instead of 10, has HD video, and is slightly more expensive.  I will post a review on the Z950 soon.My complaints and the reason I'm giving this camera 4 stars instead of 5:  The battery compartment cover is flimsy and I know it will break eventually.  The camera body is easily scratched on the shiny surfaces.  And I'm not all that impressed with the distance for macro shots.  I end up compensating on this by taking the shot from a farther distance than 5" on the highest MP setting and then cropping it down.  I've also had some trouble with shutting the macro off - I press the button on top and it gets stuck on the macro setting. And also that 5 second picture preview (called Quickview).  This may be a deal-breaker for me, I haven't yet decided if I'm returning it.One thing you have to watch out for with this camera:  The camera's speaker is located on the top left, where you'd normally hold onto the camera with your left hand.  I happen to like to hear the beeps and shutter noises, etc., and I have to constantly make myself aware of the location of my left hand when holding the camera.  And even then, the volume, when set on high, is not very loud at all.This camera has SOME internal memory but certainly not enough for taking any more than 2 or 3 pictures; I highly recommend getting a MINIMUM Class 6 SDHC card.  Make sure it's at least a Class 6, preferably a class 10, so you will have the fastest response time.  I can pretty much guarantee you won't be happy with a slow SD card.February 23, 2011 - Edited to Add this:  This camera is NOT worth the money at the price it is now, look for a newer Kodak model and the price will be cheaper with better features more than likely.

Reviews.Title: best gift she ever got.
Reviews.Author: G. Pugh "hip-hop connoisseur"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for my wife for mother's day. She tells me it's the best present I ever got her. She loves it. It's very easy to use, well built, and it takes awesome pictures. The only knock against it is the battery life. You have to step up to some quality batteries because regular batteries will drain quickly. We use Energizer lithium batteries and they last at least six times longer then regular alkaline batteries.

Reviews.Title: Very, VERY good deal for the money.
Reviews.Author: James Barkman "James E. B."
Reviews.Content: So, my last camera was stolen and I needed a new camera quick for a job I have this summer. Being low on cash, I purchased the EasyShare Z915 for $107.85. Kodak was not my first choice (I'm a Canon or Nikon guy), but it was the least expensive superzoom I could find, so I went ahead and ordered it. Boy was I surprized. This camera has excelent picture quality, the stabilized zoom works like a charm, and I love how this camera looks. It has a kind of retro look to it.  Here are the pros and cons:  PROS:* Great picture quality* Great looks* 10X optical, stabilized zoom* Panorama mode* Takes amazing macro (close-up) photos* Decent battery life on Energizer rechargables* Very comfortable to hold* Bright, vivid 2" LCD* Full manual control (shutter, apature, contrast, etc.)* Very Easy to use  CONS:* Almost all plastic construction* Flimsy shutter* Smallish LCD* No HD movie mode* The Smart Capture mode can be hit-or-miss* No real user manual included

Reviews.Title: My new camera
Reviews.Author: RLF "RLF"
Reviews.Content: I love my new camera!  I bought a digital camera about 5 years ago and I hated it.  It was not user friendly at all and of course was only about 3 megapixels and cost about $70 more than my Kodak Z915.  It also doesn't EAT batteries like my old one.  The price was also about $25 less via Amazon.com than a major electronics store that is probably BEST not to mention.

Reviews.Title: Decent camera for the size, broke after 6 months
Reviews.Author: Des
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera last September. I remember I really liked the specs, especially for a camera small enough to fit in my purse. My previous cameras were really nice but were too big to go in my purse.The camera arrived being lighter, and not seeming as well built as anything else I had ever owned. The camera did take good pictures. About 5-6 months later the lens suddenly stopped retracting in, when I turned off the camera. It was stuck out and none of the shot controls worked. I only received a 60 day warranty with the camera, so I could not return it. Short-lived camera!

Reviews.Title: Easy to use camera
Reviews.Author: dhj
Reviews.Content: I received this camera two weeks ago as a gift and I have to say that I am pleasantly surprised.  It was very easy to use right out of the box.  I just put the dial on the "Smart Capture" setting and started shooting away.  It does take a second or two for the camera to recognize the setting you are in but it's not overly slow.  One of the best features of the camera is how quickly it captures the pictures.  What I mean by that is when you press the shoot button, it captures the picture almost instantaneously.  The other cameras I have owned had a slight delay which caused some bad pics at times.The picture and video quality on the Z915 is very sharp.  I spent all week taking pictures and videos.  When I finally had it hooked up to the tv, the pics and vids came out very nicely.  It was very sharp and the colors came through beautifully.  The only negative thing about the camera is the size.  It is a bit bulky and definitely won't fit in your pocket.  On the other hand, it probably wasn't meant to.  Regardless, this is a good little camera and absolutely worth the buy.  If you are going to purchase the camera, you may want to keep an eye on the ads at Staples.  Several times this year, they had the Z915 on sale for $99.  Thanks for reading.December 17, 2010I just came back from Staples to buy this camera as a gift and the Z915 was on clearance!  It was $62 for the blue one and $45 for the black one.  Insanely great deal!

Reviews.Title: Easy to use, solid camera
Reviews.Author: Katie
Reviews.Content: I was attracted to this camera because of the 10x optical zoom. I took many sample pictures before taking it on vacation and the pictures came out beautiful! The full zoom pictures were sharp and clear. VERY easy to use which is what I wanted. If I bring it on vacation or to a function, I don't want to take 5 minutes to figure out what setting I want. I have always hated Kodak's software so I transfer the pictures from a memory card directly to my computer. It is slightly larger than some digital camera's I've had but I actually like the feel of it in my hand. You can grip it with one hand and not feel like you're going to drop it. I recommend this camera for anyone who wants to take nice pictures very easily.

Reviews.Title: kodak camera Z915
Reviews.Author: D. Stuver "RN"
Reviews.Content: All is pretty well with this camera. My only disappointment is the lack of a view-finder. I thought I could do without it but I keep trying to use it and find it uncomfortable without one.

Reviews.Title: Great value for the money
Reviews.Author: Miltonch
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera for three weeks now and this is what I have to say about it:Pros:-Value for the money. I bought it for USD 99!!! You can't find such pack of features for that money.-Magnificent 10X optical zoom. Some professional reviewers say it shows some noise at top zoom but it's more than enough if you don't work for a magazine.-Auto-rotate feature.-Intuitive customer interface.-Panorama feature. After a few attemps you will be able to take breath taking landscapes!Cons:-No adjustable compression for high megapixel pictures. It does compress them automatically.-Performance at low light conditions. Enough for family photos but you wish for a little noise reduction at night.-It can't focus really close shots (less than 3 inches). My old Samsumg did it better in that area.Conclusion:If you are a budget consumer but still need to go further than typical point and shoot, you won't get a better deal out there. I recommed it

Reviews.Title: MUY MUY BIEN
Reviews.Author: Daniel
Reviews.Content: Hola, realmente la calidad de la imagen es muy buena, el peso de una foto en la mejor resolución, anda por ahí de de los 2 y 3 megas. La nitidez es bastante alta aún con isos altos. Los controles manuales trabajan MUY bien. Cuesta que una foto salga fuera de foco. Tiene un peso bastante bonito, no es tan liviana como otras lo que a mi gusto es mejor. El estabilizador de imágenes óptico, trabaja muy muy bien. El zoom es bastante bueno, aún en fotos con el zoom al máximo el estabilizador de imagenes hace su trabajo. En la relación precio-equipo, sin duda es una gran opción, no lo duden.

Reviews.Title: "It would make a great camera for the Smokey Mountians."
Reviews.Author: CAMPJEEP
Reviews.Content: I will try to share some things I have discovered about this camera. These are just my thoughts, I hope they might help a little. Pros: 10x optical zoom with a sharp lens and good image stabilization . It shoots fast, shot to shot is 1 to 1.5 sec with out the flash and about 2 to 2.5 sec with the flash, start up time is about 2 sec.( start-up is the same as my canon SX110 ). You do not have to remember to raise the flash and it is in a nice spot on the camera.Cons: No camera is perfect at this price point. Heads up here you do not get a SD card and no A/V cable comes with the camera.* These are just my thoughts,... The camera has a nice solid feel to it, it just feels like a real camera in your hands, you can get a good grip on it. Just about the same size as the canon SX110. I would give it a 7 out of a 10 on picture quality. As point and shoots get better we often try and compare them to digital SLRs (speed, ISOs, picture quality)so I think a 7 out of a 10 is very good for a point and shoot...  A lot of the review sites blow there pictures way up and look for defects, your likely to only make 5x7 or 8x10s and not see (what they see).It makes a great vacation camera or a good on a budget family camera ( Very easy to use, large zoom and fast picture taking ). It does seem that the Z915 gets more red eye in my grandkids pictures than I would like, that just me though...(I seem to have better luck with the (preflash) than the (digital correction). It has a really flimsy plastic cover over the usb - av cable ports. I use a SD card reader to down load my pictures. I have noticed that the mode dial has moved by accident from one mode to another because it is just a tad to loose, but on the other hand it makes it easy to turn when holding it with just the one hand... I use program mode a lot and keep the ISO  to 100 ( or I use AUTO ISO in program mode ) to keep the noise down and for the sharpest picture. I have used portrait mode and the camera used 64 iso indoors and the picture looked very sharp. It's just me thinking out loud but I think these do it all auto modes slow the camera down a tad ( focus time - shot to shot time ) and auto indoors wants to use a higher ISOs (like my canons)  and that makes for to much noise in the picture (for me), try to stay at 200 or lower and 400 is stretching it but see the pictures at cabela's I took at 400iso,they came out very good.  If auto works good for you use it but don't let the iso get to high... ( NOTE portrait mode so far has used 64iso every time I have used it indoors or out).  There are some great looking pictures posted on this site using auto mode with this camera, check them out if you have time...Another thing you can try to help focus faster is to use center-zone focas instead of multi-zone. Sometimes I set the color mode to low color and like what I see sense kodak colors are so vivid anyway, just something you could try if your pictures look over processed(over done,to vivid) to fine tune your picture if you wanted.  This camera is also called a ZD15 in some stores and it will be the same camera.UPDATE 7/24/10 this morning I used program mode and the ISO was set to ( AUTO ISO ) and the camera was taking pictures at 64iso, they came out very sharp and the sports mode was using 200iso which was making for  nice pictures and doing it very quickly. And also taking grand kid pictures and other pictures using ( AUTO ISO )indoors in program mode it was using (200iso with the flash)  where my newer canons want to use 640 iso indoors, I have to say they looked very sharp at 200. With out the flash it was just using 400iso (in auto iso) while using program mode, Thats pretty good... I use energizer AA lithium batteries or 2500-2900 NI-mAH rechargeables. I just use the lithium batteries for vacation or  hloidays,  for just every day shooting I use the rechargeables. * You would not be happy with standerd AA batteries... Again, you do not get a SD card with the camera ), a 4gb card class 4 or class 6 would be a good place to start if your going to use the movie mode any at all ), you could get by with a 2gb if not using the video mode.I rate the 2.5inch LCD a 7 out of a 10 it could be a little bigger and a lot brighter but it does good in all but the brightest sun. It has 5 levels of brightness adjustments. Note that the LCD screen also dims to level 1 adjustment after 7 seconds in any shooting mode until you push any button and if you do nothing for 7 sec again it will dim again  to save the battery... This might help if your waiting to long on the quick view to go off (it takes 5 secs) and you want to get that next shot, push the shutter button 1/2 down and it will go off and focus on your next picture, you do not have to waite the full 5secs.  Canon has a 2 second review or quick view setting which is nice. I mostly keep my quick view turned off again thats just me though...I set the  disp overlay to grid lines to help take a straighter picture, You may use it for the 1/3 rule also).( Kodak calls it-capture frame grid, set to on ).If your new to this digital camera stuff remember to low level format the SD card ((save your pictures first, doing this will also erase the pictures)).Just noticed this, while taking a picture go into (scn mode)then choose landscape, take your picture and check (properties in your computer), it chose to use sharp in the sharpness setting in stead of the normal setting (for a distant picture) it new to use more sharpness in that mode ,impressive...The lowepro ( Apex 60 AW ) is a really  nice camera case for the Z915. **Check out the pictures for the Z915 on this site to get a idea how some of the options and pictures would look for you. I mostly take pictures of bear in the Smokey Mountians (CADES COVE) and love chasing the grand kids around taking their pictures.

Reviews.Title: Above expectations, Good DSRL Like camera
Reviews.Author: A. Benvenuto "GuguiNEO"
Reviews.Content: After reading several reviews of this camera, I decide to buy it over other models I checked, specially for the Zoom, AA Batteries, SDHC, and Manual Modes, I have allways owned Point and Shoot cameras but I want to be able to take photos that involved Exposure and Aperture controls, I wanted a Small size camera that had features for advance photos like a DSLR.Controls are easy to use and learn if you had a prior KODAK camera, and they are as easy as any other Digital Camera, If you set the camera on Auto Mode ( the only red icon on the Selector) Most of the Shots will turn out OK. Also there are 7 other positions for Manual mode, Shutter Priority Mode, Aperture Priority Mode, Exposition Progam, Movement Shots, Preset SCENES (museum, Night Shots, Portraits. . . . etc), Video and the good old composite panoramic shot included in my old Kodak (this is a neat feature, Take three or two shots and stich them on a expectacular wide panoramic photo)As I expected the image quality its superior than my older digital camera, however in some cases, specially indoors or low lighted areas the edges of contrast areas are very noisy (not a little, sometimes it is a lot) But as I learned to use the advance features of the camera, I use exposure modes and even the preset scenic modes to correct these shots.The Zoom and Lenses are excelent, the Tele - Wide control has a little of a delay of response at first, but still VERY GOOD and Stable, The Face detection and movement control are good. Most of the shots taken are sharp and Focused, even in long Zoomed pictures.Image Color as most of Kodak Digital Cameras, Is SUPERGOOD! the Daylight pictures are Clear, Crisp and Bright.I have not use continuos shooting mode ( as I read it only takes 3 shots), But I liked to take more than 1 picture of most portrait (or people) photos, so later on my PC I can review and select the best one. The camera has an excellent reload time between photos, its very short, specially when the photo doesn't require Flash.As someone stated in the reviews I checked, It is not very user friendly to open the battery door to remove the SD memory, I haven't let it open for more than 1 minute and the Hour, Date and setting still saved. at least for now, however it is not good for the camera to keed opening and closing these thing. I could break or get loose at any time.Some people also stated that I looked cheap, my expectations were overpass on this issue, althought its made of plastic (as most of all the less than $199 camera are) the camera its well built and designed, its even heavier than I expected. The controls, buttons, etc. are well placed and feel good. Most cameras today are plastic made, but they come with a aluminium molded shell or metalic paint over them. This Model just doesn't!I haven't installed or use the software, I use Picasa 3, an import the photos directly from the camera or through a SD Card reader.There are some features lacking in the camera that could be improved, even on a software (firmware update)CONS.- In some cases the photos are noisy, specially on the edges of things, and high contrast areas.- The SD should have a separated hatch or door.- Some long exposure photos in manual mode TAKE FOREVER TO BE PROCESSED after the shutter ended. I even though the camera was freezing or something.- USING THE ZOOM IN VIDEO MODE is useless, as you change the zoom the camera goes out of focus for a second, these makes the Video function very limited, also the VIDEO RECORDING it is NOT HD, it's only 640 x 480 pix. (I knew this before buying, I included this because most of the competitions models have it)- The only missing feature to make this camera a tuff D-SLR competitor its the Optical Viewfinder.- Printed Manual its terrible, Writen by Idiots, the user guide it's like a firs steps to use, thats all (I liked good and deep explained printed manuals, specially for a Digital Camera)- No Cloth Sleve or anything!!!! c-mon!PROS.- Super Bright, Crisp, Clear and Color photos (In good lights conditions indoors or outdoors)- Internal Memory 32Mb(I forgot to put back the SD and went to a presentation, when realized that had no memory in it, switch to low resolution photos and took almost 28 @ 1.2MP)- Excelent Shooting speed.- Easy of use, AUTO Modes, Scene Modes. ETC.- 10X Zooommmm!- Advance SHUTTER, EXPOSURE, APERTURE controls.- Good Contrast and Large Screen- Easy to charge, find and more AA Battery Supply- SD / SDHC compatibility (I don't buy any Sony, Olympus or Panasonic camera for ONLY this reason)- Panoramic Feature "stiching" 2 or 3 pictures in One- Excelent Size not too big, not too small- True Plug and Play PC compatibilty (on Windows XP)- No Pop-up Flash, I had those before and are delicated, specially if you have kids.- Some people like colored cameras, these are avaliable on red and blue, but I bought it BLACK- SLR-Like Controls and Functions.I DON'T REGRET BUYING THIS CAMERA, I'M KEEPING IT!

Reviews.Title: Overall a very good camera for the price
Reviews.Author: J. Mark "Cautious Buyer"
Reviews.Content: I was specifically looking for a compact megazoom camera, preferably one that wouldn't hurt the wallet.  I found exactly what I was looking for in this camera, the Kodak Z915.Pros: 10x optical zoom, small size, light-weight, simple to operate, bright LCD screen, AA batteriesCons: eats batteries quickly, plasticky cheap feel, auto-focus is slow especially fast motion actionFirst off, I am no professional photographer or cameraphile. All I wanted was the longer zoom capability combined with the ease and simplicity and portability of a compact point-and-shoot camera.  This camera does those things very well, and considering its low price here on Amazon (<$120) you can't really complain about its limitations. Bright vivid colors in outdoor daylight. Decent flash. Relatively small size. Very simple to operate. Ability to find emergency replacement batteries just about anywhere due to using standard AA batteries.If I could ask for more, it would be nice if it could do 720p movies instead of the max 640x480.  Most still or posed shots came out great, no real touch-up required - however, the auto-focus takes some time to lock in and for action shots it was extremely difficult to get good usable photos - they were very blurry and it seems the auto-sensing scene selector did not choose a high enough ISO for me.  It would also be nice if the camera were a bit smaller - while this camera is by no means as large as a DSLR, it is still a fair bit larger than most compact cameras, and will just barely fit in most pants pockets, but not very comfortably.  The camera body also has a somewhat cheap non-solid feel which makes me think that the first accidental drop will end up being its last - not that I plan on dropping it, of course, but still...Bottom line: I am happy with my purchase. It meets my requirements pretty well and should fit most budget.  While it is priced similarly to other budget cameras, its features clearly put it in front of all of them.  I would recommend this camera to my friends or colleagues.P.S. The Lowepro Rezo 50 case is a great fit for this camera -- very small but not tight at all, while also allowing room for spare batteries and a spare SD card.

Reviews.Title: Good Buy for the money
Reviews.Author: Floor Guy
Reviews.Content: I am a real estate appraiser & need a camera for everyday use, as well as family trips, etc. While I am not a camera expert or formal critic  I wanted a camera this time that had a good optical lens, but that would not fall apart after daily use & wouldn't break the bank. The Kodak works fine. Very easy to use and takes great shots. The only problem, & it is probably more me than the camera, is that the dial on the top of the camera that switches between the different modes does not stay in place after being removed from my pocket so I have taken a lot of videos with funny dialogs when I wanted to take a photo.  I must say the unwanted videos are also of a good quality. It fits in my pants pocket well enough and has not yet shown much wear & tear after being tossed into the car or placed into my briefcase. The flash is integrated into the body of the camera, which is a huge plus as I have had bad luck with the pop up flashes. So all in all it is a very good camera & I would buy it again.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for everyday use
Reviews.Author: cindy
Reviews.Content: I love the Easy Share 915.  Have taken great pictures, closeups and it is easy to use.  I do NOT use the disc that came with it, as I download my pics into different folders.  The Kodak discs have a tendency to want to control your files, etc.  I had an easy share before and loved that too, but I wanted one with more zoom power.  But overall, it is a great camera and I use it A LOT.  It is nice too because it uses double A betteries that can be recharged.

Reviews.Title: got a lemon
Reviews.Author: Julia C. King
Reviews.Content: In less than 6 months after purchasing this item, the lens got stuck and wouldn't zoom. I mailed it out, under warranty for repair (had to pay shipping) through Kodak. Then, less than 2 months later, it would be focused until I pressed to take a picture and then it would go blurry and all my pictures are either dark or blurry. I really was not happy with the quality of this camera.

Reviews.Title: Kodak Z915 Digital camera
Reviews.Author: Richard S. Parcells "DustyMojave"
Reviews.Content: This is quite a nice little camera. Good... no...I should say "great" bang for the buck. My wife and I have been pleased with the camera. We've had no problems with it at all. Buying it through Amazon provided us by far the best price for a camera of this particular model or of its general type. We use rechargeable AA batteries in it. Not quite as convenient as the factory rechargeable and dock in my fancier Kodak Digital. But this cost less than 1/3 of the other. The SD memory card is the best of the various types and now the most common type. They are readily available in enormous capacity for very low price.

Reviews.Title: Easy is right
Reviews.Author: Andrea
Reviews.Content: It's simple and love all the options available with this camera. Don't be scared when I say with all the options available...I'm not a professional photographer AT ALL, this camera is easy to use. Camera takes great pics. I recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Good camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Chad
Reviews.Content: This camera is an excellent value at under $100 shipped (The black camera was half the price of the blue version). The 10X optical zoom control is well placed as are the other controls. AA batteries allow the use of inexpensive rechargeables. The only downside of the camera is that it requires the use of Kodak's "Easy" Share software to upload pictures which takes time to load then is not very intuitive. Previous cameras allowed access to picture files like any other USB memory device. I've been very pleased with the picture quality and overall performance.Update: Recent trip to Smokies: great pictures indoors and out, even a campfire. Connected to a computer without Kodak software, memory was seen as USB device and could be uploaded directly. Still very pleased!!!!

Reviews.Title: I love it!
Reviews.Author: Tracey
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. The large display screen is wonderful, the buttons are easy to use and understand. The picture quality is wonderful.

Reviews.Title: Not Bad For The Money
Reviews.Author: Tank
Reviews.Content: The camera seems a little awkward or bulky at first but you get used to that quickly. Had a little problem with the usb hookup but make sure you firnly ibsert the cable into the camera and you should be fine, Also having trouble with the software because it is not compatible with windows 7.Although they have a fix for it on Kodaks website,I still had problems with it. I used Windows Photo Gallery instead and had no problems. Other than that ,everything about the camera is great!

Reviews.Title: awesome camera, awesome price.
Reviews.Content: I love this camera!!! it's kodak, so it's easy to use, of course. you can adjust the aperature and the shutter speed easily. it's good quality for a great price... i bought this with my own babysitting money so i was lucky to find a nice one for not too expensive. i would reccomend it to any 10- 12 year old photographers like me, as well as any adult photographers. i outgrew my kodak md41 too fast and i expect for this one to last a long time. i wish that the card slot was not right next to the batteries, though. the door to the batteries/card feels cheap like you could break it off too easily. so to upload it, i use the chord when i would like to use the card. great camera!

Reviews.Title: Good Camera
Reviews.Author: Z. Crawford
Reviews.Content: The camera has a built in Help system which is AWESOME and makes using the camera's settings easier. I have noticed that quite a few of the pictures taken turn out blurry. I am not an expert by any means, but I am taking my second college photography class from a notable Portland photographer, so I do know how to use the different manual settings correctly. I noticed the most blurry photos were taken under auto. I think if you hold the auto focus, let go, then hold it again the camera focuses better but of course would be a hassle. Other than that, this camera is making me happy so far. Great price for the manual settings, large LCD screen and no time limit videos. Oh, and the Panorama picture stitching is cool :)On a side note, I saw that someone was saying it was a giant hassle to upload the pictures because of the software, BUT if you just take the memory card out and slip it into the necessary computer slot, it will make things 100% smoother. No need to even use the cord. Just an FYI.

Reviews.Title: Great Quality for the Low Price
Reviews.Author: dougandlauravo
Reviews.Content: I'm a mom of two boys and I'm the kind of photographer that uses our camera on special occasions and holidays and then also when I grab it to catch a cute face or activity from my kids. I love that this camera has such a fast shutter speed. Even if you've snapped a picture and its currently on the screen you can still snap away more pictures, there's hardly any wait time, which is convienent for me. I'm still taking some time messing around with the settings to see how to get the best picture inside, outside, etc. but for the most part the auto option does a nice job. I do with this camera came with a neck stap instead of a wrist strap because it's just bulky enough that a neck strap would be helpful. Overall, a great camera that's a step up from the regular point and shoot. And a steal on the price!

Reviews.Title: How the spare camera becaim the main camera
Reviews.Author: Martin Waterhouse "Lostinspace"
Reviews.Content: For a camera that can be bought for under $100 - it's simply amazing! Excellent pictures on full auto, plenty of scope if you need to add some manual options, good videos even with decent sound. Some cool unexpected features like exposure bracketing for HDR (High Dynamic Range)picture construction sequences. Fast startup, fast focus, lots of options relatively light on the batteries. I got this as a spare camera to my Fuji SLR and my wife's Lumix, after a vacation using all 3 cameras, the Kodak ones were turning out consistently superior so it quickly became our main camera!

Reviews.Title: Really pleased!
Reviews.Author: Katie
Reviews.Content: Although my heart yearns for a professional DSLR camera, my wallet realizes it will be a while before I possess one. I decided to upgrade my old 4 MP camera for this one, and I am really glad I did!  The shots I have taken so far are superb!  The camera is really easy to use, and pictures are easy to upload (with or WITHOUT the EasyShare software).  This is not a slim, skinny camera, but that's just fine with me.  I will gladly sacrifice putting a camera in my pocket for photos like these.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Robert A. Stein
Reviews.Content: Replaced a 4x optical camera with this 10x one. I immediately replaced the batteries with my rechargeables. Very pleased with the purchase.

Reviews.Title: Good blend of size & function
Reviews.Author: Sara-s
Reviews.Content: Pros: uses AA batteries, small enough for my purse, high zoom power, can zoom in during video modeCons: blurs while zooming in video mode.I like Kodak cameras. This is my third. My other one is currently a Z981. That one is great for major trips, but sometimes I need something I can carry in my purse. So, for that, I have the Z915. It is not as tiny as the "ultra-slim" type, but still can be carried in my purse, for occasions such as parties or weddings.Plus, there are some features I want, that you will just not get in a tiny camera. Most notably, it has a 10x zoom, which I really love. Its buttons are easy to press, by feel so I don't waste time looking for them (and missing shots in the process.) I like the fact that I can easily put it into Burst Mode, for action shots.Like any camera, it takes a little practice. But after only a few hours, I was taking clear, crisp pictures in all of its modes. It's a 10MP camera with image stabilization. It would be pretty hard not to.

Reviews.Title: Easy To Use
Reviews.Author: Phillip D. Wilkerson "pwilkers"
Reviews.Content: It is so easy a blonde can use it. I bought it for my wife and she is a natural blonde. So believe me it is as it is advertised EasyShare

Reviews.Title: good camera for the price
Reviews.Author: R. Lindey
Reviews.Content: I bought this Kodak about a month ago, so have not used it extensively. My previous Kodak (650) had issues with delay time between pictures so I was very pleased to see this one had less than .3 second shutter speed. It is a way faster point and shoot. There are many options for the type of picture (beach, panoramic, night, action, etc.) and it is fairly easy to figure out. I was mainly looking for more MPs and higher zoom. This has 10 MP and 10x zoom which is really nice. I video taped my daughter's choir the other night and it is nice to be able to zoom in and out during recording, but you do lose focus momentarily. The playback sound on the camera is very muted, will have to see how it transfers to the computer. Would have liked to have a view finder for times when the screen is washed out by bright light, but for the price I paid on Amazon ($60 cheaper than same camera at Walmart), I will live without it. Also would have been nice if the camera was a little more stylish. All-in-all though, I am very happy with it.

Reviews.Title: Above and Beyond
Reviews.Author: J. Burkhart
Reviews.Content: The performance and ease of use of this camera is by far above and beyond expectations. If you shopped around for prices like I did then you found the differences to be around $60-$100. The fluctuation of prices caused me concern. I thought the quality might be questionable if prices could flex like that. But the reviews I read caused me to be curious enough to try it. I love it. It's not a $600 camera but it'll perform better than any other camera at this price point. We just had our third child and I've put it through the ringer. I would recommend looking over the manual though. This camera is a step up for me and even though it is basically a point and shoot camera to really get some awesome effects and quality there is some tweaking and steps to take that reading will help with. I know this isn't the perfect camera, exspecially for the professional photographer. But for a father of three that just takes family and vacation photos it's great. The 10x zoom, 10 megapixels, and speed between snaps is great. It's a bit bigger than my last camera but it comes with a lot more options and still fits easily in cargo pants side pockets. I would highly recommend it. Oh...and my wife would like me to mention the reading the manual thing again. Something about reading when first getting the camera not when trying to take that precious moment shot when time is of the essence. Something like that.

Reviews.Title: Nice Camera
Reviews.Author: Don8864 "loving retirement"
Reviews.Content: I can not believe that you are able to get such a great, feature rich camera for $100.

Reviews.Title: Great zoom, ok night time quality
Reviews.Author: S. Lalloo
Reviews.Content: This camera seemed like the perfect thing on the market. It was nicely priced and offered great features. It arrived in good time and great condition. The zoom is fantastic but unless you have a VERY steady had, the pictures will be blurry. As far as i see it, the only way its max zoom will work well is if you have a camera stand/tripod. Holding it in your hand whilst zooming doesnt give a good quality picture at all... The night time quality is also quite bad.. even after using alternative settings on the camera, it still isn't the best I have seen. It works terribly in false lighting such as florescent etc, but I suppose the same will apply for most cameras

Reviews.Title: Unacceptable
Reviews.Author: Eliot Press
Reviews.Content: One major issue.  Kodak does not provide a WIA driver for this camera.  To get pics out of the camera, you must use their EasyShare software (and don't get me started about how many ways that software is simply abominable).  This means that if you are on a trip, for example, or at a friend's house, and you want to upload pics out of the camera so that you can actually see them in all their 10-megapixel glory, you must find a computer that has the obnoxious EasyShare bloatware installed on it.  Every other digital camera that I have ever used, even third world knockoffs, would open as a device under "My Computer" when jacked into a USB port. Not this baby.Two minor issues.  It is difficult to seat the USB cable into the camera jack because the rubber port cover interferes.  Or maybe mine came with a flaky cable.  Either way, it took more than an hour and three annoying text chats with technical support to solve this problem.  Also, the shutter that covers the lens is delicate and flimsy.  It needs a lens cover to protect it, but none was provided, and it is not a standard size.  You would not want to put this camera into your pocket without a lens cover to protect the fragile shutter over the lens.  Good luck finding one that fits.

Reviews.Title: Not So Great
Reviews.Author: Astronomy Guy
Reviews.Content: I see all of these glowing reviews, and I think, is this the same camera I'm using? Well it is, but my results are apparently not nearly as good as what others are saying. First and foremost, I would NEVER buy another Kodak camera again that has the Easy Share feature. With most other cameras, you plug the camera into a USB port and it appears as a device that can be accessed as a hard drive. Not so with this camera. You are FORCED to either load the (very) crummy Easy Share software on your computer (or some other picture grabbing software), and use that as your interface, or yank the card out of the camera and plug it into a reader. Having had cameras in the past where the battery door broke, (and that is where SD card is), I am very leery of constantly having to access this compartment. I'm also definitely NOT getting those clear crisp pictures that other owners seem to get. I had a Nikon Coolpix 2100 that did better in some cases. This video is very good, as long as you don't try to zoom while taking the video. Talk about blurry, until it settles back into focus. Also, one reason I wanted 10 mega-pixel, is that I had heard that more pixels result in less grainy low light shots. This camera does pretty well in rooms during daylight, even without a flash, but is not good at all in a partially darkened room.

Reviews.Title: It converted an unbeliever
Reviews.Author: J. Mallinson
Reviews.Content: I had been itching for a new digital camera for a long time.  And when I say long, I mean an ice age.  My last new camera was a 3 MP unit purchased in the summer of 2003 before I took an eight-month trip abroad.  Needless to say, I make things last and I'll never be the saviour of a consumer-driven economy.My in-laws came to visit from Europe this past June, and while I'd been agitating with my wife to get a new camera to chronicle their first visit to America, I couldn't overcome her base-level skin-flintiness.  Then when the in-laws arrived, a ray of hope emerged.  My wife's grandmother had sent to each of us a little cash present.  Not feeling constrained to answer to my wife in the use of MY present, I surfed the webs and picked up this camera refurbished from B&H.;My wife was...  unimpressed.  Actually, angry was a better way to put it.  See, while our old camera was approaching the level of a piece of junk, regardless, my wife always imagined that our next camera would be a fancy DSLR job, since we'd borrowed one before and enjoyed it, and we'd also just helped her parents pick one up for her brother, who's on his way to being a professional photographer.  She said that there was no point to buying an ordinary point-and-shoot because 1) we never took pictures and 2) better to wait and buy a fancy DSLR.  My retort was that 1) we never took pictures anymore because the old camera was such a pain to use and 2) it will never make sense to get a DSLR because we'd never really need that much camera.  Needless to say, the night after I bought the Kodak Z915, we went to bed angry.Then she used it.Now, my wife and I can't be blamed for being blown away with any new piece of digital photography kit, given how long we suffered under the yoke of outdated technology.
